awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating the Air-Sea Energy Exchange in the presence of Surface Gravity Waves by Measurements of Turbulence Dissipation, Production and Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding of air-sea boundary layer processes requires a quantitative description of mixing and transport in the ocean. The development and improvement of ocean models rely on results from comprehensive observation programs that capture mid- to small-scale turbulence which is associated with energy transfer from the atmosphere to the ocean. In this project, the role of surface gravity waves in energy transfer is studied by linking the atmosphere and ocean through a unique set of turbulence measurements. These are carried out simultaneously both on the air and water sides. To elucidate air-sea wave driven turbulence, the research teams will measure the vertical structure of the turbulence kinetic energy (TKE) dissipation rate across the air-sea interface from the Air Sea Interaction Tower at Martha's Vineyard Coastal Observatory. The proposed measurements of turbulence will enhance the understanding of coupled boundary layer dynamics and will improve existing and future air-sea interaction parameterizations. The field campaign will also create a data set for the community that we will be shared through an open-access data system. This will accelerate the development of high-resolution wave coupled ocean numerical models and improve both weather and ocean conditions forecasts. Outreach through education is also a focus of this program. In addition to the support and training of a graduate student and a post-doctoral researcher, undergraduate research experiences (REU) will be provided through an existing NSF-REU program (URI) and new collaborations with local schools to expose high school students to earth sciences (UConn).

This study focuses on the energy transfer from the atmosphere to the ocean and how this occurs across the air-sea interface.  Indirect and direct observations of the energy flux divergence (wave-induced transport) on the atmospheric side will be used to constrain the magnitude of the air-sea TKE transfer rate and to provide an upper bound to the TKE injection by wave breaking (i.e. the breaker work). Direct estimates of active breaking and the resulting foam on the ocean surface will be used to provide complementary estimates of the subsurface TKE dissipation rate. On the ocean side, measurements of TKE dissipation rate and the TKE production and transport terms throughout the water column will be made using several complementary techniques. Using these measurements, the researchers will explore the expected TKE dissipation rate deficit/surplus at the interface relative to a rigid wall and assess the role of surface gravity waves in the deviations. Furthermore, an attempt will be made to elucidate and differentiate the effects of wave breaking and Langmuir Circulation driven turbulence and define characteristic turbulent scales to improve present and future mixing parameterizations in the upper ocean. On the atmospheric side, deviations from the law-of-the-wall are expected to be correlated to the energy flux divergence, which arises from wave motion creating an energy flux into the wave field. This study will characterize the wave signature on the air velocities and pressure on the atmospheric side, further elucidating the physics of the energy exchange.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit

Waves are ubiquitous on the ocean surface, yet their precise role in the transfer of energy from the atmosphere to the ocean is not understood. In atmospheric flow over land, the turbulent kinetic energy (TKE) budget consists of turbulent energy produced near the surface by friction and buoyancy, and turbulent energy dissipated by small eddies. Over the wavy ocean surface, however, the wind interacts with the waves, and turbulent energy is transferred to waves by fluctuations of pressure. Therefore, over the sea surface, TKE production is balanced by both transfer to waves and dissipation, and the TKE budget has a hypothesized deficit in dissipation. 

As waves break, creating whitecaps, they lose energy, injecting TKE into the near-surface ocean. Most of the energy transferred from the waves to the ocean is dissipated as turbulence in the near-surface ocean. Therefore, near the ocean surface, the TKE budget has a surplus of dissipation, with TKE dissipation balancing both energy input from waves and TKE production. A schematic of the TKE budgets is shown in Figure 1. The excess oceanic TKE dissipation has been well observed over the last 40 years. 

Here, using sonic measurements of the wind at multiple heights above the sea surface (setup shown in Figure 3), we determine the magnitude of the TKE dissipation deficit in the atmosphere, and the height of the wave-induced perturbations on the atmospheric side. In other words, wind measurements are used to estimate TKE production and TKE dissipation in the bottom 20 meters of the atmosphere, and the energy transfer from the atmosphere to the ocean is inferred as TKE production minus TKE dissipation (shown in the upper panel of Figure 2). Similar measurements of the TKE budget in the ocean are used to estimate the magnitude of energy transfer from the waves to the near surface ocean: energy input is estimated as the TKE dissipation minus the TKE production (lower panel of Figure 2). Finally, to directly measure the role of breaking waves, or whitecaps, in air-sea energy transfer, an image processing algorithm is applied to videos of the sea surface (visible imagery in Figure 3) in order to estimate the amount of wave breaking, and therefore, the amount of wave energy dissipation by whitecaps. 

Our results (summarized in Figure 4) show an atmospheric TKE dissipation deficit that agrees in magnitude with the subsurface TKE dissipation surplus. Additionally, the estimated energy dissipation by breaking waves agrees with these estimates of air-sea energy transfer, indicating that the air-sea energy transfer is primarily supported by breaking waves. Our observations show that energy transfer is greatest under high winds. Under very strong winds (>15m/s), the observed deficit in the atmosphere is greater than the observed surplus in the ocean, indicating energy storage in the waves in the form of wave growth.


 

Broader Impacts

The advancement of numerical weather prediction and climate models will rely heavily on our ability to describe the physical interaction between the ocean and atmosphere. The results of this project which have been disseminated thus far provide concrete and useful descriptions of the ocean’s near-surface TKE response to wind forcing.  The results from this work allow us to further our understanding of air-sea turbulent fluxes, which are strongly impacted by the short-scale wave dynamics and breaking waves and physical processes that affect them.  Furthermore, the description of ocean breaking wave dynamics provided by the work will directly improve the way in which ocean waves are modeled.  Data and code corresponding to published works are available through Columbia Academic Commons, a publicly-accessible online repository. We developed focused teaching modules on breaking wave dissipation, gravity-capillary ocean surface waves in coupled wave-current interaction, and energy exchange problems incorporated into his Air-Sea Interaction course material at Columbia University, Department of Earth and Environmental Science. Three graduate students at LDEO participated in this project, one of which graduated in the Spring 2023, and another is preparing a lead-author manuscript.  Summer interns at LDEO participated in data analysis for multiple summers.  The PI participated in the Lamont Open House.  We prepared a Teaching Module for the Earth2Class program (https://earth2class.org/site/?p=14454) in collaboration with Michael Passow.
